events.originalText: A gas leak caused an explosion that collapsed a building and led to the deaths of 22 people in Rosario, Argentina.
events.subtitle: 2013 Rosario gas explosion
events.headline: Gas leak explosion in Rosario, Argentina kills 22

events.originalText: A series of riots broke out in several London boroughs and in cities and towns across England in response to the shooting of Mark Duggan by Metropolitan Police officers.
events.subtitle: 2011 England riots
events.headline: Riots erupt across England after shooting of Mark Duggan

events.originalText: Flash floods, mudslides, and debris flows across the Ladakh region of Indian-administered Kashmir left at least 255 people dead.
events.subtitle: 2010 Ladakh floods
events.headline: Flash floods in Ladakh region of Kashmir claim 255 lives

events.originalText: Mauritanian President Sidi Mohamed Ould Cheikh Abdallahi was ousted from power by a group of high-ranking generals that he had dismissed from office several hours earlier.
events.subtitle: Sidi Ould Cheikh Abdallahi
events.headline: Mauritanian President ousted by high-ranking generals

events.originalText: On approach to Antonio B. Won Pat International Airport in Guam, Korean Air Flight 801 crashed into a hill, killing 228 of the 254 people aboard.
events.subtitle: Antonio B. Won Pat International Airport
events.headline: Korean Air Flight 801 crashes in Guam, 228 dead

events.originalText: Researchers announced that the meteorite ALH84001 (pictured), discovered in the Allan Hills of Antarctica, may contain evidence of life on Mars, but further tests were inconclusive.
events.subtitle: Meteorite
events.headline: Meteorite ALH84001 may contain evidence of life on Mars

events.originalText: British computer programmer Tim Berners-Lee posted a public invitation to collaborate on a system of interlinked, hypertext documents accessible via the Internet, known as the World Wide Web.
events.subtitle: Programmer
events.headline: Tim Berners-Lee introduces World Wide Web

events.originalText: U.S. president Lyndon B. Johnson signed the Voting Rights Act into law, outlawing literacy tests and other discriminatory voting practices that had been responsible for the widespread disfranchisement of African Americans.
events.subtitle: Lyndon B. Johnson
events.headline: Voting Rights Act signed into law by Lyndon B. Johnson

events.originalText: World War II: The U.S. Army Air Force bomber Enola Gay (pictured with crew) dropped the Little Boy atomic bomb on Hiroshima, Japan, killing about 70,000 people instantly.
events.subtitle: World War II
events.headline: Enola Gay drops atomic bomb on Hiroshima, 70,000 killed

events.originalText: New York Supreme Court judge Joseph Force Crater disappeared in Manhattan, in a case that was never solved.
events.subtitle: New York Supreme Court
events.headline: New York Supreme Court judge Joseph Force Crater disappears

events.originalText: The Anglo-Belgian India Rubber Company was founded in Antwerp to exploit natural rubber in the Congo Free State.
events.subtitle: Abir Congo Company
events.headline: Anglo-Belgian India Rubber Company founded in Antwerp

events.originalText: The Battle of Oriskany, one of the bloodiest battles of the American Revolutionary War, was fought about 6 mi (10 km) east of Fort Stanwix, New York.
events.subtitle: Battle of Oriskany
events.headline: Battle of Oriskany fought near Fort Stanwix, New York

events.originalText: Second Fitna: Pro-Alid forces defeated the Umayyad Caliphate in the Battle of Khazir, allowing them to take control of Mosul in present-day Iraq.
events.subtitle: Second Fitna
events.headline: Pro-Alid forces defeat Umayyad Caliphate in Battle of Khazir
